responses: Hi there, how can I help?
See you later, thanks for visiting

The causes are: weak fixture, axially weak workpiece,too long tool overhang, milling square shoulder with weak spindle, irregular table feed, cutting data, bad stability, vibration in corners. Please pick one
Assess the direction of the cutting forces and provide adequate support or improve the fixture
Reduce the cutting forces by decreasing the cutting depth, ap
Select a coarse and differentially pitched cutter with a more positive cutting action
Select a geometry with a small corner radius and small parallel land
Select a fine-grain, uncoated insert, or a thinner coating
Avoid machining where the workpiece has poor support against the cutting forces
. Consider a square shoulder cutter (90-degree entering angle) with positive geometry
Decrease axial cutting force-lower depth of cut, smaller corner radius and parallel land
Select a coarse-pitch cutter with differential pitch
Use coarse-pitch cutters with differential pitch
Balance radial and axial cutting forces-45 degree entering angle, large corner radius or round insert cutter
Use oversized cutters and Coromant Capto coupling adaptors
For sold carbide end mills and exchangeable-head mills, try a tool with fewer teeth and/or a higher helix angle

patterns: Milling square shoulder with weak spindle
responses: Select a positive and light-cutting cutter and insert
Check spindle deflection to see if acceptable for machine
Tighten machine fed mechanism: adjust the feed screw on CNC machine
Adjust the locking screw or replace the ball screw on conventional machines
Program large corner radii with reduced feed rate
improve chip evacuation by using rich and well directed cutting fluid or compressed air
Split deep cuts into several passes
Try up milling in deep slotting
Use solid carbide end mills or exchangeable-head mills with two or maximum three cutting edges and/or a higher helix angle

patterns: harmful for tool life and security
responses: Evacuate chips effectively by compressed air or copious cutting fluid flow- preferably internal coolant
Change cutter position and tool path strategy
Split deep cuts into several passes
The causes are: Excessive feed per revolution, built-up edge formation, back-cutting, workpiece frittering. Please choose one
Set cutter axially or classify inserts. Check height with indicator
Check spindle run-out and cutter mounting surfaces
Decrease feed per rev to max 70% of the width of the parallel land
Use wiper inserts if possible (for finishing operations)
Increase cutting speed, Vc to elevate machining temperature
Use sharp cutting edge inserts with smooth rake side
Try a cermet grade with higher cutting data
Check spindle tilt (approx.. 0.10 mm/1000 mm (0.004 inch/39 370 inch))
Arial run-out, TIR of spindle should not exceed 7 microns during finishing
Reduce the radial cutting forces (decrease the depth of cut, ap)
Check the parallelism on the parallel lands and on wiper insert used (should not be standing on heel or toe
Make sure the cutter is not wobbling-adjust the mounting surfaces
Select a close of extra-close pitch cutter
Re-position the cutter to give a thinner chip at exit
Select a more suitable entering angle (45-degrees) and lighter cutting geometry
Monitor flank wear to avoid excessive wear

patterns: burr formation material specific - HRSA/stainless steel
burr formation notch main wear mechanism
responses: Use large radius giving low insert entry angle
Keep depth of cut below radius
Go from close to coarse pitch, i.e. fewer teeth
A positive cutter is more power efficient than a negative cutter
Reduce cutting speed before table feed
Use a smaller cutter and make several passes

patterns: rapid wear causing poor surface finish or out of tolerance
execessive wear causing short tool life
responses: Evacuate chips effectively using compressed air
for sold carbide end mills and exchangeable-head mills, select a higher helix geometry (gp ≥45˚),
improve clamping of tool and workpiece

patterns: excessive wear causing a weakend edge
cutting edge breakthrough on the trailing edge causes poor surface finish
Diffusion wear due to cutting temperatures that are too high on the rake face
responses: Reduce the speed to obtain a lower temperature, and then reduce the feed

patterns: plastic deformation of edge, depression or flank impression
cutting temperature and pressure too high
responses: Select a more wear resistant (harder) grade

patterns: top side and support for insert damaged
poor surface texture and excessive flank wear
The chips are deflected against the cutting edge
responses: Select an insert with a stronger cutting edge
Reduce feed at the beginning of cut
Select an insert with a stronger geometry
Increase cutting speed or select a positive geometry
Reduce feed at the beginning of cut
Use a cutting angle closer to 45 degrees
Use round inserts for best result
Use variable ap technique to prolong the wear

patterns: small cracks perpendicular to the cutting edge
poor surface finish due to temperature variations
responses: Select a tougher grade with better resistance to thermal shocks
Cutting fluid should be applied copy or not at all

patterns: cutting edge frittering when the BUE is torn away
Cutting zone temperature is too low
Very sticky material, such as low-carbon steel stainless steel, and aluminium
responses: Change to a more suitable insert geometry

patterns: workpiece material is welded to the cutting edge
responses: Use oil mist or cutting fluid
Reduce the cutting speed, increase the number of infeeds OR Reduce the largest infeed depth, check the diameter before threading
Choose a grade with better resistance to plastic deformation

patterns: BUE ripped away together with small amounts of insert material
Often occurs in stainless steel and low-carbon steel
Unsuitable grade or cutting edge temperature too low
responses: Choose an insert with good toughness, preferably PVD coated

patterns: Wrong turned diameter prior to threading
responses: Turn to correct diameter before threading. 0.03-0.07 mm (0.001-0.003 inch) radially larger than max diameter for thread
Increase number of infeeds. Reduce size of the largest infeed
Change to C-geometry and use modified flank infeed
Wrong grade Choose a more wear resistant grade

patterns: Insert inclination angle does not agree with the thread lead angle
responses: Change method of flank infeed for F-and A-geometry: 3-5 from flank, for C-geometry: 1degree from flank
Change shim to obtain correct angle of inclination

patterns: poor surface on the thread flank
responses: Use soft jaws. When using tail stock optimize component centering hole and check pressure of tail stock/face driver
Minimize tool overhang, make sure the clamping sleeve for bars is not worn, use anti-vibration bars dedicated for thread turning
Increase cutting speed: if this does not help lower the speed dramatically and try F-geometry

patterns: The part of tre cutting edge which is not in cut is damaged by chip hammering, leading to poor surface and excessive flank wear
responses: reduce feed at the beginning of the cut

patterns: Poor surface finish and cutting edge frittering when the built-up edge is torn away
cutting zone temperature is too low
very sticky material, such as low-carbon steel, stainless steels and aluminium
responses: use oil mist or cutting fluid

patterns: excessive wear causing a weakened edge
cutting edge breakthrough on the trailing edge leading to poor surface finish
temperature variations from varying cutting fluid supply or intermittent machining leading to small cracks perpendicular to the cutting edge, insert frittering and poor surface finish
responses: apply cutting fluid in large amounts, or not at all

patterns: cutting temperature and pressure too high
rapid wear causing poor surface finish or out of tolerance
Excessive wear resulting in short tool life, burr formation on component, poor surface finish, heat generation and excessive noise
uneven wear resulting in corner damage, short tool life, bad surface finish and high noise level

responses: Reduce feed at the beginning of the cut

split axial cutting depth ap, into more than one pass
high speed machining requires shallow passes
improve clamping of tool and workpiece
